title: How many rounds did Union soldiers typically carry during the Civil War? What about Confederate soldiers? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: The cartridge box was slung on a cross chest belt or attached to your waist belt. It held 40 rounds. That’s about two pounds of lead plus powder and “tins” that held the 4 packets of ten rounds separated. Each packet held ten premade paper cartridges with around 65 grains of black powder and usually the conical “Minie-ball” fired by rifled muskets. It was not uncommon for a soldier to carry another 40 rounds in his knapsack or even in his pockets. Ready re-supply was carried in boxes of 1000 rounds carried on mules. The cartridge packets also contained a dozen caps for the nipple of the ignition system. In a hot battle men might fire a hundred rounds. But, usually far fewer. One Union Corps badge showed a cartridge box with the words “forty rounds.”  The Yankees called them “secession pills.” The cure for treason.

The Standard cartridge box carried two tins that held a pack of ten cartridges in the upper compartment and ten in the lower for a grand total of forty rounds. This was true for both Union and Confederate soldiers. In many cases, if the unit was expecting a heavy fight such as Joshua Lawrence Chamberlain of the 20th Maine did, the men might be issued two or more packs of ten cartridges or sixty rounds.
